ai-ud5.3:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-ud5.3:1.3_0: At that time in Rājagaha there was a leper called Suppabuddha.
ai-ud5.3:1.4_0: He was poor, destitute, and pitiful.
ai-ud5.3:1.5_0: On one occasion when the Buddha was seated teaching a large gathering,
ai-ud5.3:2.1_0: Suppabuddha saw the crowd seated off in the distance
ai-ud5.3:2.2_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud5.3:2.3_0: “Surely some variety of foods will be distributed there.
ai-ud5.3:2.4_0: Why don’t I approach the crowd?
ai-ud5.3:2.5_0: Hopefully I’ll get something to eat.”
ai-ud5.3:3.2_0: where he saw the Buddha teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
ai-ud5.3:3.3_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud5.3:3.5_0: this ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma in an assembly.
ai-ud5.3:3.6_0: Why don’t I also listen to the teaching?”
ai-ud5.3:3.7_0: Right there he sat down to one side, thinking,
ai-ud5.3:3.8_0: “I also will listen to the teaching.”
ai-ud5.3:4.1_0: Then the Buddha focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the Saṅgha, thinking, “Who here is capable of understanding the teaching?”
ai-ud5.3:4.2_0: He saw Suppabuddha sitting in the assembly,
ai-ud5.3:4.3_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud5.3:4.4_0: “This one here is able to understand the Dhamma”,

ai-ud5.3:4.8_0: and the advantages of renunciation, (these) he explained.
ai-ud5.3:4.9_0: When the Buddha knew that his mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
ai-ud5.3:4.10_0: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-ud5.3:4.11_0: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
ai-ud5.3:4.12_0: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma in Suppabuddha:
ai-ud5.3:4.13_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-ud5.3:5.1_0: Then Suppabuddha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He rose from his seat and went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-ud5.3:5.2_0: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
ai-ud5.3:6.2_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-ud5.3:6.3_0: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-ud5.3:6.4_0: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-ud5.3:6.5_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the Teaching, and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-ud5.3:6.6_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-ud5.3:7.1_0: After Suppabuddha had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
ai-ud5.3:7.2_0: But soon after Suppabuddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at him and took his life.
ai-ud5.3:8.1_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud5.3:8.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud5.3:8.3_0: “The leper called Suppabuddha, after being educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, has passed away.
ai-ud5.3:8.4_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-ud5.3:9.1_0: “Mendicants, Suppabuddha was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ai-ud5.3:9.2_0: according to the Teaching, and so on.
ai-ud5.3:9.3_0: and did not trouble me on account of the Dhamma.
ai-ud5.3:9.4_0: With the ending of three fetters, Suppabuddha is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-ud5.3:10.1_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-ud5.3:10.2_0: “What was the cause, sir, what was the reason why Suppabuddha became the Buddha
ai-ud5.3:11.1_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Suppabuddha was a son of a prominent merchant in this very Rājagaha.
ai-ud5.3:11.2_0: On his way to visit a park, he saw Tagarasikhi, a Buddha awakened for themselves, entering the city for alms.
ai-ud5.3:11.3_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud5.3:11.4_0: “Who is this leper wandering about with his leper’s robe?”
ai-ud5.3:11.5_0: Before leaving, he spat on the ground and turned his left side to Tagarasikhi.
ai-ud5.3:11.6_0: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.
ai-ud5.3:11.7_0: And as a residual result of that same deed, he became a leper right here in Rājagaha, poor, destitute and pitiful.
ai-ud5.3:11.8_0: But owing to faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-ud5.3:11.9_0: After relying on faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-ud5.3:11.10_0: There he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory.”
